Title: PTM093210 Applying For Fixed Protection 2016 (FP 2016)
Para: Who can make an online applications for FP 2016?

Title: PTM093210 Applying For Fixed Protection 2016 (FP 2016)
Para: Paragraph 14(3)(a) Schedule 4 Finance Act 2016

Title: PTM093210 Applying For Fixed Protection 2016 (FP 2016)
Para: An application can be made by either the member themselves or some other person on their behalf.

Title: PTM093210 Applying For Fixed Protection 2016 (FP 2016)
Para: Conditions required for a valid application for FP 2016

Title: PTM093210 Applying For Fixed Protection 2016 (FP 2016)
Para: Paragraph 14(3) Schedule 4 Finance Act 2016

Title: PTM093210 Applying For Fixed Protection 2016 (FP 2016)
Para: An application for FP 2016 must be made online on or after 6 April 2016 (see above). For the online application to be valid, certain conditions have to be met. These conditions are that the application must:

Title: PTM093210 Applying For Fixed Protection 2016 (FP 2016)
Para: be made by or on behalf of the individual concerned,

Title: PTM093210 Applying For Fixed Protection 2016 (FP 2016)
Para: contain the individual’s title, full name, full postal address and e-mail address and, where the individual is not the applicant, contain the same details for the applicant as well

Title: PTM093210 Applying For Fixed Protection 2016 (FP 2016)
Para: give the individual’s date of birth

Title: PTM093210 Applying For Fixed Protection 2016 (FP 2016)
Para: give the individual’s National Insurance number (or if they do not have a National Insurance number, give the reason for this),

Title: PTM093210 Applying For Fixed Protection 2016 (FP 2016)
Para: contain a declaration that the member meets the conditions for FP 2016 (see](#apply) 2016 {#} - introduction),

Title: PTM093210 Applying For Fixed Protection 2016 (FP 2016)
Para: contain a declaration that everything stated in the application is true and complete to the best of the applicant’s knowledge and belief,

Title: PTM093210 Applying For Fixed Protection 2016 (FP 2016)
Para: contain a declaration that the individual has met the conditions referred to in the introduction above, and

Title: PTM093210 Applying For Fixed Protection 2016 (FP 2016)
Para: contain a declaration that, in the period from 6 April 2016 to the date the application is made, no protection-cessation event (see PTM093400) has occurred in relation to the member.

Title: PTM093210 Applying For Fixed Protection 2016 (FP 2016)
Para: There is no need to give any valuation of current or expected pension funds as part of the application.

Title: PTM093210 Applying For Fixed Protection 2016 (FP 2016)
Para: Giving up enhanced protection

Title: PTM093210 Applying For Fixed Protection 2016 (FP 2016)
Para: If a member has enhanced protection on 6 April 2016 then they cannot benefit from FP 2016.

Title: PTM093210 Applying For Fixed Protection 2016 (FP 2016)
Para: Once a member has told HMRC that they plan to rely on enhanced protection they will have received a certificate with details of their protection. However, unlike primary protection a member can choose to give up enhanced protection.

Title: PTM093210 Applying For Fixed Protection 2016 (FP 2016)
Para: If a member has enhanced protection only (without primary protection) then so long as they have given this up before 6 April 2016 they can apply for FP 2016.

Title: PTM093210 Applying For Fixed Protection 2016 (FP 2016)
Para: If a member holds both primary and enhanced protection and they choose to give up enhanced protection, they will still have their primary protection. As a member cannot give up primary protection, this will stop them from benefitting from FP 2016.

Title: PTM093210 Applying For Fixed Protection 2016 (FP 2016)
Para: If an individual wishes to give up enhanced protection they must tell HMRC in writing. The relevant legislation says that in such cases, enhanced protection ceases from the date HMRC receives this written notice. So enhanced protection cannot be given up from some future date. If a member wished to keep enhanced protection until 5 April 2016 they must have ensured that HMRC received their written notice on that date. Once an individual has given up enhanced protection they cannot change their mind. Enhanced protection cannot be re-instated. If a member gets FP 2016 by giving up enhanced protection and later finds they made the wrong decision they cannot get their enhanced protection back.

Title: PTM093210 Applying For Fixed Protection 2016 (FP 2016)
Para: Will HMRC accept all applications for FP 2016?

Title: PTM093210 Applying For Fixed Protection 2016 (FP 2016)
Para: Paragraphs 14(1), (2), (4), and 16 Schedule 4 Finance Act 2016

Title: PTM093210 Applying For Fixed Protection 2016 (FP 2016)
Para: As long as the member completes the prescribed form giving all the information that is requested then the application is a valid application which will be accepted by HMRC. Where HMRC refuse to accept an application, they must notify the member who has a right to appeal against that decision (see Appeal against HMRC’s refusal to issue or decision to withdraw a reference number).

Title: PTM093210 Applying For Fixed Protection 2016 (FP 2016)
Para: How will a member know if HMRC has accepted their application for FP 2016?

Title: PTM093210 Applying For Fixed Protection 2016 (FP 2016)
Para: Paragraph 14(1) to (4) Schedule 4 Finance Act 2016

Title: PTM093210 Applying For Fixed Protection 2016 (FP 2016)
Para: When HMRC has received an application and accepted it as valid they will issue the member with a reference number unless the member already has IP 2014. This will be done online.

Title: PTM093210 Applying For Fixed Protection 2016 (FP 2016)
Para: Where the member makes a valid application for FP 2016 but has already successfully applied for IP 2014, then their application is successful on a dormant basis. This is because IP 2014 protects pension savings with a value of between £1.25 millions and £1.5 million and so protects a greater amount of pension savings than FP 2016. This means that HMRC will not issue the member with a reference number unless and until the member’s IP 2014 no longer applies (see PTM094400 for when this happens). HMRC will notify the individual accordingly. If IP 2014 no longer applies, the member must inform HMRC of this whereupon HMRC will issue the FP 2016 reference number.

Title: PTM093210 Applying For Fixed Protection 2016 (FP 2016)
Para: When HMRC may withdraw a FP 2016 reference number

Title: PTM093210 Applying For Fixed Protection 2016 (FP 2016)
Para: Paragraph 15 Schedule 4 Finance Act 2016

Title: PTM093210 Applying For Fixed Protection 2016 (FP 2016)
Para: HMRC may withdraw a reference number that they have issued to a member if

Title: PTM093210 Applying For Fixed Protection 2016 (FP 2016)
Para: something contained in the member’s application was incorrect there has been a protection-cessation event (see](https://www.gov.uk/hmrc-internal-manuals/pensions-tax-manual/ptm093400) for more detail) since their application was made

Title: PTM093210 Applying For Fixed Protection 2016 (FP 2016)
Para: the member has failed to respond within the given deadline to a notice given by HMRC under paragraph 1 of Schedule 36 to Finance Act 2008 relating to the member and FP 2016.

Title: PTM093210 Applying For Fixed Protection 2016 (FP 2016)
Para: If HMRC withdraws a member’s FP 2016 they must notify the member to tell them that they have done so and give their reasons for the withdrawal. The member may appeal against the withdrawal of their reference number.

Title: PTM093210 Applying For Fixed Protection 2016 (FP 2016)
Para: Appeal against HMRC’s refusal to issue or decision to withdraw a FP 2016 reference number

Title: PTM093210 Applying For Fixed Protection 2016 (FP 2016)
Para: Paragraph 16 Schedule 4 Finance Act 2016

Title: PTM093210 Applying For Fixed Protection 2016 (FP 2016)
Para: Where HMRC has refused to accept a member’s application for FP 2016, they must notify the member that their application has been unsuccessful. The member may appeal against this decision to the First-tier or Upper-tier Tribunal as appropriate. The member may similarly appeal against HMRC’s decision to withdraw their reference number.

Title: PTM093210 Applying For Fixed Protection 2016 (FP 2016)
Para: The member must tell HMRC if they want to appeal against the refusal to issue a reference number or the withdrawal of their reference number and they must do this within 30 days of the date when the notification of refusal/withdrawal was given. An appeal cannot be made where the application has been successful on a dormant basis (see How will a member know if HMRC has accepted their application for FP 2016?).

Title: PTM093210 Applying For Fixed Protection 2016 (FP 2016)
Para: Where the appeal is considered by the tribunal and relates to the refusal to issue a reference number, the tribunal will allow the appeal if the tribunal is satisfied that:

Title: PTM093210 Applying For Fixed Protection 2016 (FP 2016)
Para: the application was a valid application (see Conditions required for a valid application for FP 2016)

Title: PTM093210 Applying For Fixed Protection 2016 (FP 2016)
Para: everything in the application was correct, and

Title: PTM093210 Applying For Fixed Protection 2016 (FP 2016)
Para: that, at the time of their decision, withdrawal of the requested reference number would not, had it been issued, be authorised either because a protection-cessation event has occurred or because the individual has failed to comply, within the required time, with a notice they have been given under Paragraph 1 of Schedule 36 to Finance Act 2008 to provide information or a document to HMRC to allow their tax position to be checked.

Title: PTM093210 Applying For Fixed Protection 2016 (FP 2016)
Para: If the above grounds are not satisfied the tribunal must dismiss the appeal.

Title: PTM093210 Applying For Fixed Protection 2016 (FP 2016)
Para: If the tribunal finds that HMRC should have accepted the notice then HMRC must issue the member with a FP 2016 reference number.

Title: PTM093210 Applying For Fixed Protection 2016 (FP 2016)
Para: Where the appeal is considered by the tribunal and relates to the withdrawal of a reference number, the tribunal will allow the appeal if the tribunal is satisfied that the withdrawal was not authorised on the grounds set out at When HMRC may withdraw a reference number.

Title: PTM093210 Applying For Fixed Protection 2016 (FP 2016)
Para: Notifying subsequent protection-cessation events

Title: PTM093210 Applying For Fixed Protection 2016 (FP 2016)
Para: Paragraph 17 Schedule 4 Finance Act 2016

Title: PTM093210 Applying For Fixed Protection 2016 (FP 2016)
Para: An individual must notify HMRC if a protection-cessation event (see PTM093400) has occurred at a time when any of the following circumstances apply:

Title: PTM093210 Applying For Fixed Protection 2016 (FP 2016)
Para: the individual has been issued with a reference number following a successful application for FP 2016,

Title: PTM093210 Applying For Fixed Protection 2016 (FP 2016)
Para: the individual has a pending application for a FP 2016 reference number. A pending application is one where either the individual has made an application but does not yet know if it has been successful (i.e. they have not been issued with a reference number) or the application has been unsuccessful but an appeal is in progress against HMRC’s refusal to issue a reference number (an appeal, including a further appeal, is in progress for so long as it has not been either withdrawn or determined and there is no prospect of further appeal, or

Title: PTM093210 Applying For Fixed Protection 2016 (FP 2016)
Para: an appeal is in progress against HMRC’s decision to withdraw the individual’s FP 2016 reference number.

Title: PTM093210 Applying For Fixed Protection 2016 (FP 2016)
Para: Where any of the above circumstances apply, the individual must notify HMRC that the protection-cessation event has occurred. The notice must be given within 90 days of the day on which the individual could first reasonably be expected to have known that the event has occurred. The notice must be given either using the online facility provided by HMRC for this purpose or by any other means authorised by HMRC in a particular case.

Title: PTM093210 Applying For Fixed Protection 2016 (FP 2016)
Para: What happens if the member dies before they have made an application for FP 2016?

Title: PTM093210 Applying For Fixed Protection 2016 (FP 2016)
Para: Paragraph 19 Schedule 4 Finance Act 2016

Title: PTM093210 Applying For Fixed Protection 2016 (FP 2016)
Para: Where the member dies before making an application for FP 2016, their personal representatives (PRs) are able to do anything in relation to applying for FP 2014 that the member could have done.

Title: PTM093210 Applying For Fixed Protection 2016 (FP 2016)
Para: So all of the above guidance applies to PRs in such circumstances. Where the application is being made by the member’s PRs there is a further condition for a valid application (see Conditions {#} required for a valid application for FP) namely that the application must contain the individual’s date of death as well as their date of birth.

Title: PTM093210 Applying For Fixed Protection 2016 (FP 2016)
Para: If, after the individual’s death, HMRC decides to withdraw a reference number issued to the individual (see When HMRC may withdraw a reference number) they must give the notice of, and reasons for, to the individual’s PRs.

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: A pension scheme’s rules may include an earnings cap. This means that the pension scheme’s definition of final pensionable salary includes a cap on the amount of a member’s earnings that counts as pensionable salary. The cap may change with the tax year (for example the continued operation of the earnings cap under pre 6 April 2006 tax legislation).

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: Where a member has applied for one of the fixed protections and their pension scheme’s rules include an earnings cap, an increase in the cap will lead to the loss of the fixed protection where this results in benefit accrual.

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: Example

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: James is a member of a registered pension scheme. The scheme provides a pension benefit (before commutation for a pension commencement lump sum) of 1/60th of pensionable earnings for each year of service.

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: The scheme’s rules contain an earnings cap which increases every 6 April by an amount equal to the annual increase in the RPI for the year ending with the preceding month of September, rounded up to the nearest multiple of £600.

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: On 6 April 2013 the scheme’s cap is £150,000.

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: For tax year 2013-14, James has earnings of £200,000.

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: On 5 April 2014 James has completed exactly 30 years of pensionable service. James has therefore accrued a pension of £75,000 (£150,000 x 30/60). That is also the amount he has accrued immediately after midnight on 5 April 2014.

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: For FP 2014 purposes James’s pension rights are valued at £1.25 million (£75,000 x 20 = £1.5 million) and James has successfully applied for FP 2014.

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: The annual increase in the RPI between September 2012 and September 2013 is say 5.6%.

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: On 6 April 2014 the scheme’s earnings cap increases to £158,400 (£150,000 @ 105.6/100 = £158,400. There is no rounding up as £8400 is an exact multiple of £600).

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: James has remained in active membership of his scheme; under the scheme’s rules his benefits are increased by reference to his length of service and final salary (subject to the earnings cap) rather than by a percentage specified in the scheme’s rules.

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: For the purposes of the benefit accrual test, the relevant percentage (see](https://www.gov.uk/hmrc-internal-manuals/pensions-tax-manual/ptm093600) for more detail) in James’s case is the higher of the appropriate CPI percentage increase and the relevant statutory increase percentage. The CPU percentage increase is the 5.2% increase (say) in the CPI between September 2012 and September 2013. This is higher than any relevant statutory increase percentage that may apply to James’s benefit. So, in James’s case, the relevant percentage for tax year 2014-15 is 5.2%.

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: This is less than the 5.6 % increase in James’s rights as a result of the increase in the earnings cap.

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: Benefit accrual has therefore occurred on 6 April 2014 and James loses his FP 2014 from that date.

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: The benefit accrual test for defined benefits in a tax year during which the member takes their benefits

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: When a member takes defined benefits in a tax year, whether or not there is benefit accrual at any time is calculated on the basis of their prospective benefits.

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: The test is carried out on any increase(s) in the value of the member’s prospective pension and lump sum rights occurring throughout the year, ending with the point in time immediately before the BCE(s) occur(s) in relation to the benefits taken.

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: In the case of an active member whose benefits accrue on the basis of final salary and years of service, since this does not involve increasing the rights of active members by a rate specified in the scheme’s rules, the ’relevant percentage’ (see](https://www.gov.uk/hmrc-internal-manuals/pensions-tax-manual/ptm093600) for more detail) will be the appropriate annual increase in the CPI unless a higher relevant statutory increase percentage applies in which case that higher percentage is the relevant percentage.

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: If on this basis benefit accrual does occur at some time during the tax year before benefits are taken then the fixed protection is lost at the point the relevant percentage is exceeded.

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: If, later in the same tax year, those benefits are taken early and are subject to an actuarial reduction, then even though the value of the benefits taken may at that stage be less than the value of those benefits when they were calculated under the benefit accrual test, this does not alter the position and the fixed protection remains lost.

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: Top of page

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: Death-in-service benefit for members with fixed protection who ceases to accrue any further pension benefits in their employer’s defined benefits scheme

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: Under the tax rules it is possible for death-in-service benefits to be provided for individuals with deferred pension benefits. However a pension scheme may choose not to provide death in service benefits if a member stops being an active member. This will depend on the rules of the scheme.

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: Whether or not an individual can continue to have death benefits (life cover) and keep their fixed protection depends on the type of arrangement providing the death benefits. If the death benefit promised is a defined benefit (and this is often the case in occupational pension schemes) continuing to provide death cover should not cause loss of the fixed protection. This is because a death-in-service benefit is not considered to be part of a member’s defined benefit pension rights. So if a member continues to be provided with death-in-service defined benefits this is not benefit accrual and does not cause loss of the fixed protection.

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: If the death benefit promised is on the basis of an other (i.e. non-cash balance) money purchase benefit, cover may only continue with the member keeping their fixed protection if it is provided by a policy established before 6 April 2006. The conditions at PTM093100 must be met. Fixed protection is lost where contributions are made to a policy set up on or after 6 April 2006.

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: Top of page

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: The consequences where a scheme insures against lump sum death benefits and continues payment of premiums for a member with any of the fixed protections

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: If the death benefit promised is on the basis of an other (i.e. non-cash balance) money purchase benefit, cover may only continue with the member keeping their fixed protection if it is provided by a policy established before 6 April 2006. The conditions at PTM093100 must be met. Fixed protection is lost where contributions are made to a policy set up on or after 6 April 2006.

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: Where the only lump sum death benefit being provided under an arrangement under the scheme rules is an amount equivalent to the proceeds of an insurance policy, in other words, there is no provision for a defined benefits lump sum death benefit, then the arrangement is clearly an other money purchase arrangement.

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: Where the lump sum death benefit is expressed as being the greater or lesser of:

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: a defined benefit (an amount determined by reference to salary, service or some other factor) and

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: the policy proceeds,

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: then this is a hybrid arrangement. This is because, depending on the circumstances when the member dies, either a defined benefit or a money purchase benefit that is not cash balance will be payable.

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: Benefit accrual occurs in relation to both an other money purchase arrangement and a hybrid arrangement capable of paying such money purchase benefits where a relevant contribution is paid under the arrangement on or after:

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: 6 April 2012 in the case of FP 2012)

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: 6 April 2014 in the case of FP 2014, or

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: 6 April 2016 in the case of FP 2016.

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: In each case, the payment of insurance premiums on or after the relevant dates result in benefit accrual and loss of fixed protection if the premium is a ‘relevant contribution’ as defined by paragraph 14 of Schedule 36 to Finance Act 2004 by virtue of paragraph 14(11) of Schedule 18 Finance Act 2011 for FP 2012, paragraph 1(10) of Schedule 22 to Finance Act 2013 for FP 2014 and paragraph 3(4) of Schedule 4 Finance Act 2016 for FP 2016.

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: However, there are a number of other scenarios in which insured lump sum death benefits may be paid. Where the death benefit being paid is not a money purchase benefit that is not cash balance, continuing payment of premiums after 5 April 2012, 5 April 2014 or 5 April 2016 as appropriate will not be benefit accrual and so the fixed protection is not lost. The following are examples of scenarios where there is no benefit accrual if insurance premiums continue to be paid.

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: Note: For the purpose of these examples, the defined benefits lump sum death benefit to be provided is assumed to be a lump sum of 4 times final salary. In practice, the defined benefit may be different (such as a specified sum or by reference to a different multiple of salary), and any increase in the value of defined benefit after 5 April 2012, 5 April 2014 or 5 April 2016 as appropriate is not benefit accrual.

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: Examples

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: A lump sum death benefit of 4 times final salary is paid out of scheme funds. This benefit is a defined benefits lump sum death benefit.

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: A lump sum death benefit is backed by an insurance policy where, if the policy proceeds exceed the promised lump sum death benefit, the excess is paid to the scheme for the provision of other benefits under the scheme.

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: A lump sum death benefit is backed by an insurance policy with the scheme liable to make good any shortfall where the proceeds of the policy are insufficient to fully fund the cost of the promised lump sum death benefit.

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: A lump sum death benefit is calculated as above and is backed by an insurance policy which will not pay out more than the promised lump sum death benefit but may contain restrictions. These restrictions, if applicable, will result in an amount payable to the scheme (or payable directly to the beneficiary(ies) which is less than the unrestricted promised defined benefits lump sum death benefit.

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: Many insurance policies contain such restrictions as terms of the policy. Examples include when there is a ‘catastrophe’ event resulting in multiple deaths of individuals covered by the policy or a reference to a particular individual who represents a greater insurance risk. If the lump sum death benefit paid to the beneficiaries after the restriction is applied can itself be expressed as a defined benefits lump sum death benefit then it will be treated as such. This can occur where the benefit

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: represents a percentage of the defined benefits lump sum death benefit that would have been provided in normal circumstances.

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: it is paid on a pro rata basis to the defined benefits lump sum death benefit that would have been provided in normal circumstances

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: it is expressed as a specified amount lower than 4 times final salary, or

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: the maximum paid under the policy is capped at a specified amount.

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: The exact position will depend upon the restrictions that apply under a particular policy. Provided the maximum lump sum death benefit that can be provided under the policy is the defined benefits lump sum death benefit of 4 times final salary and the restricted lump sum death benefit is defined in a manner which satisfies either the definition of defined benefits or, possibly, a benefit under a cash balance arrangement there will be no other money purchase element to the benefits to be provided. Where, under a group life policy, there are restrictions applying to one or more particular members covered by the policy but they do not apply to a member with fixed protection, then no account need be taken of those restrictions in deciding whether that member’s benefit is a defined benefits lump sum death benefit.

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: An individual has restricted benefits under one policy but a further policy is taken out by the scheme in respect of the individual to ensure that the maximum 4 times final salary lump sum death benefit is paid. The aggregated benefits under the two policies will be a defined benefits lump sum death benefit, subject to the top-up policy not itself being an other money purchase arrangement because the entire proceeds will be paid out as a lump sum death benefit.

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: The insurance policy might, for example, make provision for a maximum dependants’ pension equal to 30 per cent of the member’s salary, but with the pension restricted to the ‘free-cover’ divided by a specified multiple (say 30). So, if the free-cover is £500,000, the maximum dependant’s pension is £16,667. This is a defined benefit, as a specified benefit (a pension) will be provided and that pension is calculated by reference to a factor, rather than just the amount available for the provision of dependants’ benefits.

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: Top of page

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: People whose life cover ceased because they believed the continuing payment of premiums would lead to loss of their fixed protection

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: In such cases, re-instatement of the life cover is not regarded as involving a new arrangement for the member so long as:

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: the cover was re-instated as soon as possible whether with the same or a new insurer, and

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: the basis of the cover provided has not been increased in comparison to the cover previously provided.

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: Top of page

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: Refunds of contributions on death in service

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: Under scheme rules a lump sum death benefit may include an amount equal to a multiple of salary or a set monetary amount together with a refund of the contributions paid to the scheme by the deceased member.

Title: PTM093520 Defined Benefits Arrangements - Aspects Of ‘Benefit Accrual’
Para: HMRC’s view is that the payment of a refund of contributions on death is a defined benefit and that the aggregate lump sum is a defined benefits lump sum death benefit. Where the rules also provide for the refund to include an element of ‘interest’ or growth to be paid, then provided that the scheme rules provide for the payment and it is expressed or can be expressed in percentage terms then this will not affect the defined benefits nature of the lump sum. The scheme rules may specify an annual percentage rate of ‘interest’ or a rate in line with the average annual base rate of a bank etc. or a rate to be determined by the scheme trustees in accordance with actuarial advice. Such rules are accepted as providing a defined benefit.

Title: PTM094310 Valuing Pension Savings For Individual Protection 2016
Para: The lifetime allowance provisions apply only to that part of the scheme that has befitted from UK tax relief. This is known as the ‘relevant relieved amount’. At any BCE under a relieved non-UK pension scheme’ the amount crystallised by the BCE is limited to the ‘untested portion’ of the ‘relevant relieved amount’. PTM113420 explains how to calculate the ‘relevant relieved amount’ and the ‘untested portion’. But in broad terms the untested portion is that part of the member’s relevant relieved amount that has not been subject to a BCE.

Title: PTM094310 Valuing Pension Savings For Individual Protection 2016
Para: To find amount D assume that a BCE occurs at the end of 5 April 2016 for uncrystallised rights held under a relieved non-UK pension scheme. Amount D is the untested portion for this assumed BCE. Where the member has more than one relieved non-UK pension scheme amount D is the total of the untested portions.

Title: PTM094310 Valuing Pension Savings For Individual Protection 2016
Para: Example

Title: PTM094310 Valuing Pension Savings For Individual Protection 2016
Para: On 6 January 2007 Pravesh became a relieved member of a relieved non-UK pension scheme. That is the only scheme of which he is a member. Pravesh crystallises £300,000 on 6 July 2012. This is Pravesh’s first BCE from the scheme.

Title: PTM094310 Valuing Pension Savings For Individual Protection 2016
Para: At this point Pravesh has been a relieved member of the relieved non-UK pension scheme for five and a half years. Pravesh’s total pension input amounts for the previous six tax years (2006-2007 to 2011-2012) are £400,000 and his pension input amount for the period from 6 April 2012 to 6 July 2012 is £15,000. Immediately before his BCE Pravesh’s relevant relived amount is £415,000 and this is his first BCE his untested portion is also £415,000.

Title: PTM094310 Valuing Pension Savings For Individual Protection 2016
Para: Pravesh needs to value his pension savings for IP 2016. He has had no pension input amounts under the scheme since his BCE in June 2012. At the end on 5 April 2016 Pravesh’s relevant relieved amount is £415,000 and his untested portion is £115,000 (£415,000 less the previous £300,000 BCE).

Title: PTM094310 Valuing Pension Savings For Individual Protection 2016
Para: Amount D for Pravesh is £115,000.

Title: PTM113100 International: Overview Of When UK Tax Charges Apply To Non-UK Schemes
Para: Tax charges under Schedule 34 Finance Act 2004

Title: PTM113100 International: Overview Of When UK Tax Charges Apply To Non-UK Schemes
Para: Schedule 34 Finance Act 2004

Title: PTM113100 International: Overview Of When UK Tax Charges Apply To Non-UK Schemes
Para: The Pensions Schemes (Application of UK Provisions to Relevant Non-UK Schemes) Regulations 2006 - SI 2006/207

Title: PTM113100 International: Overview Of When UK Tax Charges Apply To Non-UK Schemes
Para: Schedule 34 provides for certain tax charges that normally apply to, or in relation to registered pension schemes to also apply in certain circumstances to members of non-UK pension schemes that are not registered pension schemes.

Title: PTM113100 International: Overview Of When UK Tax Charges Apply To Non-UK Schemes
Para: This is necessary as there are circumstances in which a non-UK scheme that is not a registered pension scheme will contain funds that have benefited from UK tax relief similar to, or originating from a registered pension scheme. For example, where a migrant individual comes to the UK as a member of an overseas pension scheme, any subsequent contributions to their overseas scheme may benefit from UK tax relief similar to contributions to a registered pension scheme. Also, funds in an overseas pension scheme which have built up in a registered pension scheme before being transferred to the overseas pension scheme may equally have benefited from UK tax relief.

Title: PTM113100 International: Overview Of When UK Tax Charges Apply To Non-UK Schemes
Para: Schedule 34 applies three main types of charge to members of non-UK schemes. These are

Title: PTM113100 International: Overview Of When UK Tax Charges Apply To Non-UK Schemes
Para: the various charges referred to as the member payment charges and the taxable property unauthorised payment charge (see PTM113200),

Title: PTM113100 International: Overview Of When UK Tax Charges Apply To Non-UK Schemes
Para: the annual allowance charge (see PTM113300) and

Title: PTM113100 International: Overview Of When UK Tax Charges Apply To Non-UK Schemes
Para: the lifetime allowance charge (see PTM113400).

Title: PTM113100 International: Overview Of When UK Tax Charges Apply To Non-UK Schemes
Para: However, for members of non-UK pension schemes, these specific charges are targeted only at payments that relate to the part of the member’s overseas pension fund that has benefited from UK tax relief.

Title: PTM113100 International: Overview Of When UK Tax Charges Apply To Non-UK Schemes
Para: Schedule 34 modifies the way these specific charges operate to extend their application to these non-UK schemes. Further modifications are contained in The Pension Schemes (Application of UK Provisions to Relevant Non-UK Schemes) Regulations 2006 - SI 2006/207.

Title: PTM113100 International: Overview Of When UK Tax Charges Apply To Non-UK Schemes
Para: UK tax charges can apply to a non UK scheme if:

Title: PTM113100 International: Overview Of When UK Tax Charges Apply To Non-UK Schemes
Para: a member has benefited from migrant member relief (see PTM111200), transitional corresponding relief (see PTM111500), double taxation relief (see PTM111600), or relief under section 307 Income tax (Earnings and Pensions) Act 2003 (ITEPA), or

Title: PTM113100 International: Overview Of When UK Tax Charges Apply To Non-UK Schemes
Para: when a transfer has been made to a qualifying recognised overseas pension scheme (QROPS).

Title: PTM113100 International: Overview Of When UK Tax Charges Apply To Non-UK Schemes
Para: Details are shown in the table below.

Title: PTM113100 International: Overview Of When UK Tax Charges Apply To Non-UK Schemes
Para: The overseas transfer charge

Title: PTM113100 International: Overview Of When UK Tax Charges Apply To Non-UK Schemes
Para: Sections 244A to 244N Finance Act 2004

Title: PTM113100 International: Overview Of When UK Tax Charges Apply To Non-UK Schemes
Para: A transfer from a QROPS or former QROPS may be subject to the overseas transfer charge. This is a tax charge of 25% of the ‘transferred value’ of the transfer. The scheme manager and member are jointly and severally liable to pay the tax charge. Not all transfers are subject to the overseas transfer charge. For guidance on when this charge will apply go to PTM102200.

Title: PTM113100 International: Overview Of When UK Tax Charges Apply To Non-UK Schemes
Para: Liability to the overseas transfer charge can also arise after a transfer to a QROPS due to a change in circumstances. ](https://www.gov.uk/hmrc-internal-manuals/pensions-tax-manual/ptm102400) explains when liability to the overseas transfer charge arises after a transfer.

Title: PTM125500 Pre A-Day Investments
Para: Works done wholly to comply with a statutory requirement or requirement of a public body will not endanger protection. An example of this would be work done to comply with fire safety requirements of a fire authority. However this does not extend to work that is undertaken to satisfy such regulations as part of a wider scheme of improvement of the property.

Title: PTM125500 Pre A-Day Investments
Para: In the case of an investment-regulated pension scheme that before 6 April 2006 was a self-invested personal pension (SIPP) or a small self-administered scheme (SSAS) improvement work on a property that was held indirectly at 6 April 2006 will lose protection if that work was begun on or after 5 December 2005. If that work is not substantially completed until on or after 6 April 2006 then the property will become taxable property when it is substantially completed. If the work was substantially completed before 6 April 2006 it will become taxable property at that date. In either case the amount of the unauthorised payment is the market value on that date. This value is also taken as the acquisition cost for any capital gains calculation that is made in order to determine the amount of the scheme chargeable payment when the property is disposed of.

Title: PTM125500 Pre A-Day Investments
Para: Section 590 Schemes

Title: PTM125500 Pre A-Day Investments
Para: If a scheme was approved under the mandatory provisions of section 590 Income and Corporation Taxes Act 1988 after 5 December 2005 it has no transitional protection for any interests in taxable property held at 6 April 2006. If the pension scheme holds any such interest it is treated for the taxable property charges as acquiring the interest at market value on 6 April 2006. The amount of the unauthorised payment is the market value on that date. This value is also taken as the acquisition cost for any capital gains calculations to determine the scheme chargeable payment on disposal.

Title: PTM125500 Pre A-Day Investments
Para: Top of page

Title: PTM125500 Pre A-Day Investments
Para: Extension of transitional protection for indirect holdings

Title: PTM125500 Pre A-Day Investments
Para: There is transitional protection where a pension scheme legitimately held indirect interests at 6 April 2006 and the indirect vehicle after that date acquires interests in taxable property. There are different conditions for residential property and tangible moveable property.

Title: PTM125500 Pre A-Day Investments
Para: An example of these indirect interests is an investment-regulated pension scheme that before 6 April 2006 was a Small Self-Administered Scheme (SSAS) was permitted to invest in shares of any unquoted company up to a limit of 30% of the voting power or 30% of the dividend rights.

Title: PTM125500 Pre A-Day Investments
Para: The six conditions for transitional protection to apply in respect of residential property are:

Title: PTM125500 Pre A-Day Investments
Para: the pension scheme acquired the interest in the vehicle that it holds on 6 April 2006 before that date

Title: PTM125500 Pre A-Day Investments
Para: the pension scheme was not prohibited from holding the interest in the vehicle before 6 April 2006

Title: PTM125500 Pre A-Day Investments
Para: immediately before 6 April 2006 the vehicle had a residential property rental business and held five or more residential properties for that rental business

Title: PTM125500 Pre A-Day Investments
Para: between 6 April 2006 and the date when the vehicle acquires a direct interest in residential property, the pension scheme never holds an interest in the vehicle that it would have been prohibited from holding if it had held that interest immediately before 6 April 2006

Title: PTM125500 Pre A-Day Investments
Para: the vehicle acquires the direct interest in residential property for the purposes of its property rental business

Title: PTM125500 Pre A-Day Investments
Para: the property once acquired is not occupied or used by a member of the pension scheme or by a person connected with such a member.

Title: PTM125500 Pre A-Day Investments
Para: The four conditions for transitional protection to apply in respect of tangible moveable property are:

Title: PTM125500 Pre A-Day Investments
Para: the pension scheme acquired before 6 April 2006 the interest in the vehicle that it holds on that date

Title: PTM125500 Pre A-Day Investments
Para: the pension scheme was not immediately before 6 April 2006 prohibited from holding that interest in the vehicle

Title: PTM125500 Pre A-Day Investments
Para: between 6 April 2006 and the date on which the vehicle acquires a direct interest in the tangible moveable property, the pension scheme never holds an interest in the vehicle that it would have been prohibited from holding if it had held that interest immediately before 6 April 2006

Title: PTM125500 Pre A-Day Investments
Para: the vehicle acquires the interest in the property for the purposes either of a trade, profession or vocation it carries on or of the vehicle’s administration or management.

Title: PTM125500 Pre A-Day Investments
Para: Top of page

Title: PTM125500 Pre A-Day Investments
Para: Extension of transitional protection for indirect holdings: Loss of protection

Title: PTM125500 Pre A-Day Investments
Para: Protection will be lost as set out in the following paragraphs. The indirect holding becomes taxable at the date of the first trigger event and the amount of the unauthorised payment is the market value on that date. This value is also taken as the acquisition cost for any capital gains calculations to determine the amount of the scheme chargeable payment on the disposal of the property.

Title: PTM125500 Pre A-Day Investments
Para: Residential Property

Title: PTM125500 Pre A-Day Investments
Para: Transitional protection is lost in respect of residential property when:

Title: PTM125500 Pre A-Day Investments
Para: the pension scheme’s interest in the vehicle, which holds the property directly, changes such that the pension scheme would have been prohibited from holding that interest if the pension scheme had held it immediately before 6 April 2006

Title: PTM125500 Pre A-Day Investments
Para: the property ceases to be used for the purposes of the person’s property rental business

Title: PTM125500 Pre A-Day Investments
Para: the property is occupied or used by a member of the pension scheme or by a person connected with such a member.

Title: PTM125500 Pre A-Day Investments
Para: Tangible Moveable Property

Title: PTM125500 Pre A-Day Investments
Para: Transitional protection is lost in respect of tangible moveable property when either:

Title: PTM125500 Pre A-Day Investments
Para: the interest the pension scheme has in the vehicle, which holds the property directly, changes such that the pension scheme would have been prohibited from holding that interest if the pension scheme had held it immediately before 6 April 2006

Title: PTM125500 Pre A-Day Investments
Para: the tangible moveable property, while still held by the vehicle directly, ceases to be used for the purposes either of the trade, profession or vocation it carries on or for the vehicle’s administration or management.

Title: PTM125500 Pre A-Day Investments
Para: Top of page

Title: PTM125500 Pre A-Day Investments
Para: Summary

Title: PTM125500 Pre A-Day Investments
Para: Most of the transitional protection rules were set out in a technical note issued on the day of the 2005 pre-budget report (PBR) (5th December 2005). The table below sets out the announcement that was made at that time and sets out the transitional provisions by reference to different scheme types.

Title: PTM125500 Pre A-Day Investments
Para: Clarification and guidance on the pre 6 April 2006 pension rules can be found at

Title: PTM125500 Pre A-Day Investments
Para: There will be no protection for any off-plan purchases made after PBR Day.

Title: PTM125500 Pre A-Day Investments
Para: Where a property was purchased by a SSAS under the pre 1991 rules the investment will be protected, provided it is not materially improved (unless for a statutory requirement) after midnight on PBR day. There will be no protection if there is any post-PBR material improvement expenditure (unless for a statutory requirement).

Title: PTM125500 Pre A-Day Investments
Para: There will be no protection if the indirect investment is not allowed under the current regime.

Title: PTM125500 Pre A-Day Investments
Para: No protection for any investments in residential property made by small mandatory approved schemes set up and approved after midnight on PBR day.

Title: PTM125500 Pre A-Day Investments
Para: in the table PBR means 5 December 2005

Title: PTM125500 Pre A-Day Investments
Para: in the table A-Day means 6 April 2006.

Title: PTM125500 Pre A-Day Investments
Para: All terminology and reference to scheme types relates to the pension rules applying pre A Day. Refer to the relevant pre A-Day guidance manuals for those schemes for any clarification of the terms and rules.

Title: PTM125500 Pre A-Day Investments
Para: Purchases regarded as having been made

Title: PTM125500 Pre A-Day Investments
Para: In the table above, a purchase is regarded as having been made where:

Title: PTM125500 Pre A-Day Investments
Para: both exchange of contracts and completion; or conclusion of unconditional missives and the settlement of the transaction, has taken place before the appropriate time (the appropriate time will, depending on the context, be either midnight on PBR day or midnight on 5 April 2006)

Title: PTM125500 Pre A-Day Investments
Para: exchange of contracts or conclusion of unconditional missives takes place before the appropriate time, or

Title: PTM125500 Pre A-Day Investments
Para: there is some other binding obligation to purchase before the appropriate time.

Title: PTM125500 Pre A-Day Investments
Para: Purchases regarded as not having been made

Title: PTM125500 Pre A-Day Investments
Para: A purchase will not be regarded as having been made at the appropriate time where:

Title: PTM125500 Pre A-Day Investments
Para: exchange of contracts or conclusion of unconditional missives takes place after the appropriate time, or

Title: PTM125500 Pre A-Day Investments
Para: the scheme is not legally bound to purchase prior to the appropriate time so, for example, the purchase of an option to buy property would not count.

Title: PTM125500 Pre A-Day Investments
Para: Improvement expenditure is regarded as having been made before an appropriate time where:

Title: PTM125500 Pre A-Day Investments
Para: the scheme has, before that time, entered into a binding contract for the work to be carried out, or

Title: PTM125500 Pre A-Day Investments
Para: the work is not subject to a binding contract, but, before that time, a substantial amount of the works have been carried out.

Title: PTM125500 Pre A-Day Investments
Para: Where a SIPP had acquired a property - for example off-plan - with the intention of holding it as an investment but as a result of the taxable property changes announced at the 2005 pre-budget report the decision was taken to dispose of that property it is not axiomatic that this disposal would be classified as “trading”. Each situation is decided on its own particular facts and general guidance regarding the approach to be taken in determining whether a transaction is to be regarded as trading or investment can be found in the Business Income Manual from BIM60000 onwards.

Title: PTM125500 Pre A-Day Investments
Para: But if the asset was acquired with the intention to hold as an investment (See BIM60030) and was disposed of following the taxable property changes, unless there has been a change of intention (of the type discussed in BIM60060) normally resulting in some form of physical change to the asset, this transaction is unlikely to be regarded as a trading one.

Title: PTM125500 Pre A-Day Investments
Para: In the case of off-plan, the fact that it was in the process of being developed at 5 December 2005 in accordance with the contract originally entered into between the developer and the SIPP, would not make it a trading transaction for the SIPP where the development continues.

Title: PTM145300 Conditions For Authorised Surplus Payments
Para: For this purpose a member is ‘connected’ to a sponsoring employer at the date of death where:

Title: PTM145300 Conditions For Authorised Surplus Payments
Para: if the sponsoring employer is a partnership

Title: PTM145300 Conditions For Authorised Surplus Payments
Para: the member is ‘connected’ with a partner in the partnership, or

Title: PTM145300 Conditions For Authorised Surplus Payments
Para: ‘connected’ with a person who was a partner in the partnership at any time during the year preceding the member’s death

Title: PTM145300 Conditions For Authorised Surplus Payments
Para: or

Title: PTM145300 Conditions For Authorised Surplus Payments
Para: if the sponsoring employer is a company:

Title: PTM145300 Conditions For Authorised Surplus Payments
Para: the member is, at the date of death, a ‘controlling director’ of the company, or

Title: PTM145300 Conditions For Authorised Surplus Payments
Para: was a ‘controlling director’ of the company at any time in the year preceding the member’s death, or

Title: PTM145300 Conditions For Authorised Surplus Payments
Para: the member is ‘connected’ with a person who is a ‘controlling director’ of the company at the date of the member’s death, or

Title: PTM145300 Conditions For Authorised Surplus Payments
Para: was a ‘controlling director’ of the company at any time during the year preceding the member’s death.

Title: PTM145300 Conditions For Authorised Surplus Payments
Para: Guidance on whether a person is ‘connected’ with another person is at PTM027000

Title: PTM145300 Conditions For Authorised Surplus Payments
Para: A ‘controlling director’ is a director to whom section 450 and 452 Corporation Tax Act 2010 applies (re-written from section 417(5)(b) with (3),(4)and(6)) of the Income and Corporation Taxes Act 1988).

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: there is a pension input amount for a possible other money purchase provision (‘amount B’) and a pension input amount for a possible defined benefits provision (amount C) only and amounts B and C are the same, or

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: there is a pension input amount for a possible cash balance provision (amount A), a pension input amount for a possible other money purchase provision (amount B) and a pension input amount for a possible defined benefits provision (amount C) and amount C is the same as whichever is the greater of amounts A and B

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: amount C does not apply and the pension input amount for the hybrid arrangement for the relevant tax year is taken as amount A or B, as applicable for the hybrid arrangement concerned.

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: Where there are such pension input amounts for the hybrid arrangement, the pension input amount for the possible other money purchase or cash balance provision is used as part of the money purchase annual allowance test instead of the pension input amount for the possible defined benefits provision.

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: Pre-14 October 2014 hybrid arrangements

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: A pre-14 October 2014 hybrid arrangement means an arrangement that has been a hybrid arrangement from a date before 14 October 2014 and has continuously remained a hybrid arrangement since that date up to any point during the pension input period for the arrangement ending in the relevant tax year.

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: 14 October 2014 hybrid arrangements

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: A 14 October 2014 hybrid arrangement means a hybrid arrangement that was made on or after 14 October 2014 or an arrangement which became a hybrid arrangement (whether or not for the first time) on or after 14 October 2014.

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: Alternative annual allowance

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: The alternative annual allowance means the annual allowance for the tax year concerned less the money purchase annual allowance.

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: For tax years 2017-18 onwards, the alternative annual allowance is £36,000 (being £40,000 less £4,000).

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: For tax year 2016-17, the alternative annual allowance is £30,000 (being £40,000 less £10,000).

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: Top of page

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: Pension savings statements content - for tax year 2015-16 only

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: Tax year 2015-16 is split into two ‘mini’ tax years for annual allowance purposes (see PTM058010 for more details).

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: Despite this, when required to do so, a single pension savings statement is issued for tax year 2015-16.

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: When a standard pension savings statement must be given for tax year 2015-16 is explained in PTM167100.

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: The circumstances for when a money purchase pension savings statement must be given for tax year 2015-16 are the same as those for a later tax year (See list at Top of page).

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: Standard pension savings statement - content for tax year 2015-16

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: The standard pension savings statement for tax year 2015-16 must contain all the following information:

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: the total of the pension input amounts for the member for all their arrangements under the scheme for the pre-alignment tax year

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: the total of the pension input amounts for the member for all their arrangements under the scheme for the post-alignment tax year

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: the total of the pension input amounts for the member for all their arrangements under the scheme for the previous three tax years (i.e. tax years 2014-15, 2013-14, 2012-13), and

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: the amount of the annual allowance for the previous three tax years (i.e. tax years 2014-15, 2013-14, 2012-13).

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: Note: the amount of the annual allowance for tax year 2015-16 does not have to be included.

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: Money purchase pension savings statement - content for tax year 2015-16

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: The money purchase pension savings statement for tax year 2015-16 must contain all the following information:

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: amounts 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5, as applicable, for the member under the scheme for the pre-alignment tax year

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: amounts 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5, as applicable, for the member under the scheme for the post-alignment tax year

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: the annual allowance for each of the three previous tax years (i.e. tax years 2014-15, 2013-14, 2012-13), and

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: the total of the pension input amounts for the member for all their arrangements under the scheme for the previous three tax years (i.e. tax years 2014-15, 2013-14, 2012-13).

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: Note: the amount of the money purchase and alternative annual allowances for tax year 2015-16 do not have to be included.

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: Amounts 1 to 5 for the pre and post-alignment tax years are the same as those described in the section Money purchase pension savings statements content – for tax years 2016-17 onwards above.

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: Top of page

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: Information about tax year 2015-16 as a previous tax year

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: The sections Standard pension savings statements content - for tax years 2016-17 onwards and Money purchase pension savings statements content – for tax years 2016-17 onwards above each explain that a pension savings statement for a current tax year must contain certain information relating to the previous three tax years.

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: When a pension savings statement for a current tax year includes tax year 2015-16 as one of the three previous tax years for which information must be given, the information given for tax year 2015-16 as previous tax year is modified as follows.

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: Tax year 2015-16 as a previous tax year in a standard pension savings statement

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: In a standard pension savings statement that includes information for 2015-16 as a previous tax year, the following applies in respect of that 2015-16 previous tax year information:

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: the total of the pension input amounts for the member for all their arrangements under the scheme for tax year 2015-16 must be provided separately for the pre and post-alignment tax years, and

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: the annual allowance amount for tax year 2015-16 does not have to be provided.

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: Tax year 2015-16 as a previous tax year in a money purchase pension savings statement

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: In a money purchase pension savings statement that includes information for 2015-16 as a previous tax year, the following applies in respect of that 2015-16 previous tax year information:

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: where the scheme administrator had reason to believe that the money purchase annual allowance applied to the member for tax year 2015-16

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: amounts 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5 (as applicable) for tax year 2015-16 must be provided separately for the pre and post-alignment tax years,

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: there is no requirement to state that the member’s ‘money-purchase input sub-total’ for tax year 2015-16 will be tested against a £10,000 allowance, and

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: there is no requirement to give an alternative annual allowance amount for tax year 2015-16, or

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: where the scheme administrator did not have reason to believe that the money purchase annual allowance applied to the member for tax year 2015-16

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: the total of the pension input amounts for the member for all their arrangements under the scheme for tax year 2015-16 must be provided separately for the pre and post-alignment tax years, and

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: the annual allowance amount for tax year 2015-16 does not have to be provided.

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: Amounts 1 to 5 for this purpose are described in the section](#Moneypurchase) above.

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: Also, even if the scheme administrator had reason to believe that the money purchase annual allowance applied to the member for the 2015-16 tax year, because a standard pension savings statement is being given in this case, a single pension input amount is given for each of the pre and post-alignment tax years and not any of amounts 1 – 5 (as described in the section Money purchase pension savings statements content – for tax year 2016-17 or later above).

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: Judy is building up benefits in three arrangements under a single registered pension scheme; a defined benefits arrangement, a hybrid arrangement that has remained so since before 14 October 2014 and an other money purchase arrangement.

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: For 2017-18 Judy’s pension input amount for her defined benefits arrangement was £40,000 and £3,000 for the other money purchase arrangement. For the hybrid arrangement the benefits which may be provided were defined benefits or other money purchase. The pension input amount for the defined benefits provision was £3,000 and the pension input amount for the other money purchase provision was £2,000.

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: The scheme administrator has reason to believe that Judy is subject to the money purchase annual allowance for tax year 2017-18 but not for any previous tax years.

Para: The total pension input amount exceeds the annual allowance of £40,000 for the tax year.

Para: The alternative annual allowance for tax year 2017-18 is £36,000 (£40,000 less £4,000).

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: The scheme administrator must send a money purchase pension savings statement because the total of Judy’s pension input amount for the other money purchase arrangement (£3,000) and pension input amount for the other money purchase provision in relation to the hybrid arrangement (£2,000) exceeds £4,000.

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: Her pension scheme administrator must send Judy a money purchase pension savings statement by 6 October 2018.

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: Judy’s pension input amounts for the previous three tax years are:

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: Format of pension savings statement

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: The format of the pension savings statement has not been set by legislation. It is up to scheme administrators to decide the format of their pension savings statements. However in designing processes scheme administrators should bear in mind all of the following:

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: the need for an audit trail. A scheme needs evidence to satisfy the member and HMRC that they have complied with the requirement to provide a pension savings statement. HMRC may enquire into an individual’s tax return. So individuals will need evidence to back up what they say on their tax return,

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: all the information must be given as a single source,

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: the requirement to keep information set out at PTM160200, and

Title: PTM167200 Other Information Requirements For Scheme Administrators: Information That Must Be Included In The Pension Savings Statement
Para: the ability of the member to be able to receive the information. For example a member may not have internet or e-mail access. Alternatively the member may have a visual impairment which makes using electronic communication difficult without using specialist software or equipment.

Title: SDLTM09800 Condition D - General
Para: Leaving an assured shorthold tenancy will not count as a disposal unless the tenancy was granted for a period of more than 7 years. Equally for Condition D, such a tenancy taken between the sale of the old property and purchase of the new property will be ignored so long as it is not granted for a term of more than 7 years.

Title: SDLTM09800 Condition D - General

Title: TSEM1705 Trust Deeds: HMRC Policy On Trust Deeds
Para: Copies or originals

Title: TSEM1705 Trust Deeds: HMRC Policy On Trust Deeds
Para: FA2008 Schedule 36, section 8(1) allows us to accept copies of documents. You should normally accept copy trust deeds.

Title: TSEM1705 Trust Deeds: HMRC Policy On Trust Deeds
Para: You should not routinely ask to see the original trust deed if you have been supplied with a copy. However, it may be appropriate to request the original document, for example, where detail on the copy is unclear, incomplete, or there is doubt about its authenticity.

Title: TSEM1705 Trust Deeds: HMRC Policy On Trust Deeds
Para: If you do need to access the original document, you can make a written request to see it. There is guidance on requesting original documents at CH229900.

Title: TSEM1705 Trust Deeds: HMRC Policy On Trust Deeds
Para: Commenting on a trust deed

Title: TSEM1705 Trust Deeds: HMRC Policy On Trust Deeds
Para: It is not HMRC policy to advise on the interpretation of trust deeds. It is the trustee’s responsibility to interpret the terms of the trust, complete the tax return and self-assess accordinlgy. If they are in doubt then their accountant or solicitor should be able to help.

Title: TSEM1705 Trust Deeds: HMRC Policy On Trust Deeds
Para: Decline any request to comment on a trust deed. Explain that it is not HMRC policy.

Title: TSEM1705 Trust Deeds: HMRC Policy On Trust Deeds

Title: VATREG25350 Change Of EDR To A Later Date
Para: Additionally, we may have to allow such requests if there has been an element of Departmental error. It is important to ensure that there are no doubts as to the EDR requested by the trader when processing VAT 1 applications. As outlined in VATREG25200, contact the trader if any information regarding the EDR needs clarification. The importance of this approach has been highlighted by the tribunal cases of AJ & AE Rowe t/a Arthurs (LON/95/423A), Simon Damels and Stuart Stevenson trading as Homeforce (LON/02/58), and Yee Mei Yeung (MAN/02/405) which the Department lost.
